briefing.opening: Good morning/afternoon, everyone. We will now begin the climate briefing for January 11, 2026.

sections.title: ğŸ”´ Climate Crisis: Threatening Daily Life and Nature
sections.content: Recent events occurring domestically and internationally clearly demonstrate the severe impact of climate change on our daily lives and nature. Domestically, climate change is directly impacting livelihoods and culture, with declining fish catches, erratic crop flowering seasons, and even disruptions to local festivals [2]. Internationally, destructive wildfire damage has been reported, such as the Longwood bushfire in central Victoria, Australia, which engulfed numerous homes and livestock [24]. In the Marin region of the United States, despite recent floods, negative perceptions of climate change still persist [21]. Furthermore, the psychological and social repercussions are growing, with anxiety about the climate crisis even leading to an individual's decision regarding abortion [25]. Bill Gates has warned of the potential failure to address climate change and urged strong government policy intervention [8].

sections.title: ğŸ‡°ğŸ‡· Strengthening Domestic Climate Change Adaptation and Research Capabilities
sections.content: In response to this crisis, the Republic of Korea is accelerating efforts to strengthen its climate change adaptation strategies and expand research capabilities. The National Institute of Environmental Research (NIER) is strengthening national-level research infrastructure by reorganizing its mid-to-long-term research system and establishing comprehensive plans to actively respond to climate change [1, 4, 5]. Local governments are also making specific adaptation efforts. Jeju Province is fully committed to climate change response by changing major crop varieties to suit the changing climate and promoting the digital transformation of agriculture [3, 6, 9]. Gangwon Special Self-Governing Province is building safe coastal and port areas in preparation for climate change [7], and Pyeongchang County is expanding its irrigation facility support project to prepare for droughts, thereby developing adaptation measures tailored to local characteristics [10].

sections.title: ğŸŒ± Domestic Energy Transition and Reduction Efforts for Carbon Neutrality
sections.content: In addition to adaptation efforts, domestic energy transition and carbon emission reduction initiatives are being pursued in various ways to achieve carbon neutrality. SK is entering the Gumi Carbon Neutral Industrial Complex and participating in the second bidding for the ESS Central Contract Market, leading the expansion of energy storage systems in the private sector [11]. In local communities, Dongshin University and Naju Daesil Village have signed an agreement to resolve regional issues related to energy transition and carbon neutrality, establishing a win-win cooperation model [12]. Seoul National University, the top carbon emitter among single institutions in Seoul, is committed to reduction efforts based on the recognition that there are ample ways to reduce carbon emissions [14]. Korea Southern Power (KOSPO) is contributing to the development of renewable energy technology by being the first power generation company to build and open 100,000 cases of renewable energy AI training data [15]. Furthermore, Changwon City is raising public awareness of carbon neutrality by exhibiting winning entries from the 'Carbon Neutrality, The Future We Draw' drawing contest [13].

sections.title: ğŸŒ Accelerated Climate Action and Policy Changes in the International Community
sections.content: The international community is also accelerating actions and seeking policy changes to address the climate crisis. Various methods for developing countries to advance climate action through innovation and technology are being presented, emphasizing the importance of global cooperation [18, 20]. Regarding policy changes, Hawaii has begun implementing a tourism tax to combat climate change [19]. Australia's lead negotiator for COP31 has announced plans to lobby oil-producing nations like Saudi Arabia for a phase-out of fossil fuels at the next UN climate summit, signaling international pressure [23]. Meanwhile, China is set to abolish export subsidies for solar products starting April 2024 and gradually reduce subsidies for battery products, which is expected to significantly impact the global renewable energy market [16]. Concurrently, universities in various countries are hosting lectures on climate change, raising public awareness and encouraging the participation of future generations [22].

briefing.closing: The domestic and international trends we have examined in today's briefing once again highlight the urgency of responding to climate change, as well as the importance of efforts from various stakeholders. Our sustained attention and action are required to overcome the climate crisis. This concludes today's climate briefing.

articles.title: China to Abolish Solar Panel Export Subsidies in Aprilâ€¦Batteries from Next Year
articles.original_title: ì¤‘êµ­ íƒœì–‘ê´‘ ìˆ˜ì¶œ ë³´ì¡°ê¸ˆ 4ì›” íì§€â€¦ë°°í„°ë¦¬ëŠ” ë‚´ë…„ë¶€í„°
articles.description: Amid controversies over global unfair competition and regressive competitive patterns, investigations into food delivery market competition are also underway, targeting 'domestic rights.' With China's dominance in global industries, the impact on exports is expected to be minimal. Solar panels installed in the desert of Qinghai, inland China. Photographed on April 23, 2024. / Xinhua News Agency. China will abolish export subsidies for solar products starting this April. Export subsidies for battery products will be phased out this year and abolished next year.Â·Â·Â·

summary.phenomenon: China will abolish export subsidies for solar products starting April 2024, and export subsidies for battery products will be gradually reduced this year and abolished from 2025.
summary.cause: This abolition of subsidies aims to resolve the regressive competitive patterns arising from controversies over global unfair competition.
summary.outlook: Due to China's established dominance in global industries, the impact on exports is expected to be minimal.

articles.original_title: Australiaâ€™s Cop31 chief negotiator plans to lobby petrostates on fossil fuel phaseout
articles.description: Exclusive: Chris Bowen says key to next UN climate summit will be â€˜engagement, engagement, engagementâ€™ with countries such as Saudi ArabiaFollow our Australia news live blog for latest updatesGet our breaking news email, free app or daily news podcastChris Bowen wants to use his stint as the worldâ€™s chief climate negotiator to lobby Saudi Arabia and others to stop resisting progress at UN summits, heeding calls for a â€œhard-nosedâ€ approach in dealing with big emitters obstructing the transition.A

summary.phenomenon: Chris Bowen, Australia's chief negotiator for COP31, plans to lobby oil-producing nations such as Saudi Arabia at the next UN climate summit to phase out fossil fuels.
summary.cause: This is due to oil-producing nations obstructing progress at UN summits and hindering the transition away from fossil fuels.
summary.outlook: Bowen intends to persuade major emitters to cease their resistance through a 'hard-nosed' approach, in response to their obstruction of the transition.

articles.original_description: Exclusive: Chris Bowen says key to next UN climate summit will be â€˜engagement, engagement, engagementâ€™ with countries such as Saudi ArabiaFollow our Australia news live blog for latest updatesGet our breaking news email, free app or daily news podcastChris Bowen wants to use his stint as the worldâ€™s chief climate negotiator to lobby Saudi Arabia and others to stop resisting progress at UN summits, heeding calls for a â€œhard-nosedâ€ approach in dealing with big emitters obstructing the transition.A

articles.original_title: â€˜It was calm â€¦ and then just hecticâ€™: David Rigby couldnâ€™t escape the Longwood bushfire so faced the inferno
articles.description: Rigby saved his Yarck home, but many were lost. Another resident says: â€˜No one actually knows how bad it is. So many livestock are deadâ€™Get our breaking news email, free app or daily news podcastOn the outskirts of Yarck, a small farming town in central Victoria, the ground is still smouldering. Gumtrees are flickering with flames as white ash whips through the air.Across the region, houses are reduced to warped steel, with brick chimneys often the only thing left standing. summary.phenomenon: The Longwood bushfire occurred on the outskirts of Yarck, a small farming town in central Victoria, Australia, resulting in the loss of many homes and livestock. The ground continues to smolder, and eucalyptus trees are engulfed in flames.

articles.original_title: I had an abortion due to climate anxiety. How can I come to terms with it? | Ask Annalisa Barbieri
articles.description: Counselling should help, but it sounds as if you need to slow down and give yourself time to grieveI am 37 years old, happily married and have two children, who came along quickly after we married in my late 20s. I instantly fell in love with them. However, I wasnâ€™t really emotionally or practically ready, and developed postnatal anxiety.Iâ€™ve always cared about the climate crisis, and since after having kids, and knowing it will affect their lives more than mine, I became motivated to make c

summary.phenomenon: A 37-year-old woman decided to have an abortion due to anxiety about the climate crisis.
summary.cause: This decision stems from concerns that the climate crisis will have a greater impact on her children's lives, leading to climate anxiety.
summary.outlook: It appears that seeking counseling and allowing oneself time to grieve would be beneficial.
